BugBoard
  • Documentation
https://

Target Locked 


            

          

          


            

            

            

              

                
                
                
                
                
                
                

              

            

            

              


              
              
              
                

                       Amass is an open-source tool designed for information gathering, specifically in the context of cybersecurity and penetration testing.
                       Developed in Go, Amass focuses on the enumeration of subdomains and associated information to help security professionals, researchers,
                       and ethical hackers understand the attack surface of a target. It provides a wide range of features for discovering and mapping network assets.
                   

                   


                   
Key Features


                   
    
                       
  1. Subdomain Enumeration: Amass is particularly effective at discovering subdomains associated with a given domain.
                           It employs various techniques, including active DNS enumeration, brute-force subdomain guessing, and passive data sources.
                       
    2. 

                       
  2. IP Address Discovery: In addition to subdomains, Amass can identify IP addresses associated with the target domain,
                           providing a more comprehensive understanding of the network infrastructure.
                       
    3. 

                       
  3. Integration with Other Tools: Amass can be easily integrated with other security tools in the reconnaissance
                           and information gathering phase. For example, it can output results that can be piped into tools like Nmap, Masscan, or httprobe for further analysis.
                       
    4. 

                       
  4. Passive DNS Enumeration: Amass supports passive DNS data sources, allowing it to retrieve historical DNS records,
                           which can be valuable for understanding changes and trends over time.
                       
    5. 

                       
  5. API Integration: It can be configured to work with API keys from various services, such as Shodan, Censys, and others,
                           to enhance the information gathering process.
                       
    6. 

                       
  6. Flexible Output Formats: Amass supports different output formats, including plaintext, JSON, and CSV.
                           This flexibility makes it easy to integrate the tool into existing workflows and processes.
                       
    7. 

                       
  7. Recursive Enumeration: Amass can perform recursive subdomain enumeration, meaning it can discover subdomains of already identified subdomains,
                           providing a more thorough map of the target's attack surface.
                       
    8. 
                   


                   

                       Amass is widely used by security professionals and penetration testers to conduct thorough reconnaissance before launching more targeted security assessments.
                       It helps in identifying potential vulnerabilities and areas of concern within an organization's network infrastructure.
                       As with any security tool, it is important to use Amass responsibly and in compliance with ethical guidelines and legal regulations.
                   

            
            
            


            
              Domain Enumeration
              Recursive Subdomain Enumeration
              Bruteforce Subdomains
              Integration with Other Tools
              Filtering Results
              Include Passive DNS Data
              help

              
              amass enum -d example.com
            
              

              
              amass enum -d example.com -recursive
            
              

              
              amass enum -d example.com -brute -w wordlist.txt
            
              

              
              amass enum -d example.com | httprobe
            
              

              
              amass enum -d example.com-exclude subdomain1.example.com
            
              

              
              amass enum -d example.com -passive
            
              

              
              amass documentation
            
              


            
            

              


              


                
                

                 

                     

                         Subfinder is an open-source subdomain discovery tool designed for penetration testers and security professionals.
                         It is written in Go and is actively maintained on GitHub. Subdomains are additional, smaller domain names that are part of a larger domain.
                         Enumerating subdomains can be crucial for security assessments as they expand the attack surface and help in identifying potential vulnerabilities.
                     


                     
Key Features of Subfinder:


                     
    
                         
  1. Subdomain Enumeration: Subfinder is primarily used for discovering subdomains associated with a given domain.
    2. 

                         
  2. Multiple Enumeration Methods: It supports various methods for subdomain discovery, including passive sources, brute-force, and recursive enumeration.
    3. 

                         
  3. Brute-Force Subdomain Enumeration: Subfinder can perform brute-force subdomain enumeration by attempting to guess subdomains using a predefined wordlist.
    4. 

                         
  4. Output Formats: It provides the flexibility to save the results in different output formats such as JSON, CSV, etc.
    5. 

                         
  5. Integration with Other Tools: Subfinder can be easily integrated with other tools and scripts in the security testing toolkit, allowing for a comprehensive assessment.
    6. 

                         
  6. API Integrations: It supports integration with API keys for certain services, enhancing the subdomain discovery process.
    7. 
                     


              
              
     

              
                Basic Subdomain Enumeration
                Recursive Subdomain Enumeration
                Output
                Integration with Other Tools
                Using Api-keys
                Passive Subdomain Enumeration
                help

                
                subfinder -d example.com
              
                

                
                subfinder -d example.com -recursive
              
                

                
                subfinder -d example.com  -o output.txt
              
                

                
                subfinder -d example.com | httprobe
              
                

                
                subfinder -d example.com -o output.txt -v -nW -t 20 -c YOUR_CERTSPOTTER_API_KEY
              
                

                
                subfinder -d example.com -passive
              
                

                
                useful documentation
              
                


              

 
              

              

                
                

                     

                         Assetfinder is a command-line subdomain discovery tool written in Go.
                         It aids security professionals, penetration testers, and researchers in identifying and enumerating subdomains associated with a given domain.
                         Assetfinder is designed to enhance the reconnaissance phase of security assessments, helping to map the attack surface of a target.
                     


                     
Key Features of Assetfinder:


                     
    
                         
  1. Subdomain Enumeration: Assetfinder is primarily used for discovering subdomains associated with a specified domain.
    2. 

                         
  2. Output Formats: It supports various output formats, allowing users to save results in different ways such as plaintext, JSON, etc.
    3. 

                         
  3. Integration with Other Tools: Assetfinder can be easily integrated with other tools in the security testing toolkit.
                             For example, the results can be piped into tools like httprobe for identifying active web servers among the discovered subdomains.
                         
    4. 

                         
  4. Recursive Subdomain Enumeration: Assetfinder can perform recursive subdomain enumeration, helping discover subdomains of already identified subdomains.
    5. 

                         
  5. API Integrations: Some features of Assetfinder require API keys for integration with external services.
                             For instance, integrating with services like Virustotal for additional information about subdomains.
                         
    6. 

                         
  6. Filtering Results: Users can filter and manipulate the results using standard Unix utilities like grep to extract specific information.
    7. 

                         
  7. Flexible Configuration: Assetfinder provides configuration options that allow users to customize its behavior, such as setting API keys for specific services.
    8. 
                     


                     

              
              


              
                Basic Subdomain Enumeration
                Recursive Subdomain Enumeration
                Output
                Integration with Other Tools
                Using Api-keys

                help

                
                assetfinder example.com
              
                

                
                assetfinder example.com -subs-only
              
                

                
                assetfinder example.com  > output.txt
              
                

                
                subfinder -d example.com | httprobe
              
                

                
                assetfiner example.com --set-config VirustotalAPIKey=YOUR_VIRUSTOTAL_API_KEY
              
                


                
                asset github
              
                


              
              




                

              


                
                
              

                  Dnsgen is a tool primarily used for generating permutations of domain names to be used in the process of subdomain discovery.
                  It's often used by security professionals, penetration testers, and researchers to create a list of potential subdomains that could be associated with a target domain.
                  By creating variations and permutations of domain names, `dnsgen` aids in expanding the scope of subdomain enumeration.
              


              
Key Features of dnsgen:


              
    
                  
  1. Basic Domain Name Generation: dnsgen example
    2. 

                  
  2. Output to a File: dnsgen example -o output.txt
    3. 

                  
  3. Brute-Force Subdomains: dnsgen -w wordlist.txt -o output.txt
    4. 

                  
  4. Add Prefix and Suffix: dnsgen -q prefix -w wordlist.txt -s suffix -o output.txt
    5. 

                  
  5. Specify TLDs: dnsgen example -t .com,.net -o output.txt
    6. 

                  
  6. Use Multiple Wordlists: dnsgen -w wordlist1.txt,wordlist2.txt -o output.txt
    7. 

                  
  7. Generate IPv6 Addresses: dnsgen -6 example -o output.txt
    8. 
              




              
              



              
                Basic Subdomain PEnumeration


                help

                
                cat subdomains.txt | dnsgen - > output.txt
              
                


                
                dns github
              
                


              
              



              

              

                
                

              

              MassDNS is a C language-based tool that is simple and has high-performance DNS root resolver capability for those who seek to resolve a massive number of domain names in the order of billions. Without suitable configuration, MassDNS is steady at resolving 346000 words per second using publicly available resolvers. MassDNS tool is a single-threaded tool designed for situations in which the network scope is massive. Only finding Subdomains of the Target domain is not important; most of them aren’t live anymore, so it would be better to remove them from your list or subdomains.txt. If you perform the mass scanning, then you can filter out the active or live hosts. MassDNS is intended to be run in servers with high-speed upload and download bandwidths. Internally, the MassDNS tool uses a hash map technique to control the concurrency of domain lookups.
              


              

              
              


              
                Basic Subdomain PEnumeration


                help

                
                assetfinder example.com –subs-only | massdns -r lists/resolvers.txt -o S -w resolved.txt
              
                


                
                massdns gfg
              
                


              
              



              

              


                

                
                



                      

                          HttProbe is a tool commonly used in the field of web application security and penetration testing.
                          Its primary purpose is to probe a list of domain names or hostnames to identify which ones have active HTTP and HTTPS services.
                      


                      
Key Features of httprobe:


                      
    
                          
  1. HTTP and HTTPS Probing: httprobe sends both HTTP and HTTPS requests to check for active web servers.
    2. 

                          
  2. Output Formatting: It formats the results in a way that makes it easy to identify which servers are responding to HTTP and HTTPS requests.
    3. 

                          
  3. Protocol Options: Users can specify which protocols to probe, allowing flexibility in testing for both HTTP and HTTPS or just one of them.
    4. 

                          
  4. Custom Ports: The tool may provide options to specify custom ports for HTTP and HTTPS probing.
    5. 

                          
  5. Redirect Following: Some versions of httprobe might include an option to follow redirects, showing the final destination of a URL after any redirections.
    6. 

                          
  6. Timeout Configuration: Users may have the ability to set a timeout for each probe, determining how long the tool waits for a response before considering a server as unresponsive.
    7. 

                          
  7. Exclusion of Unreachable Hosts: The tool may have an option to exclude hosts that are determined to be unreachable from the results.
    8. 

                          
  8. JSON Output: httprobe might support output in JSON format, facilitating easy integration with other tools or scripts.
    9. 
                      


                     

              
              


              
                Basic command


                help

                
                cat domains.txt | httprobe
              
              
                


                
                httprobe github
              
                


              
              



              

              


                

                
                

                  

                      Aquatone is a web application analysis tool designed to capture screenshots of websites and perform other tasks related to web security and reconnaissance.
                      It is commonly used by security professionals and penetration testers to visually inspect web assets and identify potential security issues.
                  


                  
Key Features of Aquatone:


                  
    
                      
  1. Website Screenshot Capture: Aquatone captures screenshots of websites to provide a visual overview of web assets.
    2. 

                      
  2. Integration with Subdomain Enumeration: The tool can be integrated with subdomain enumeration tools to perform comprehensive analysis on a target's subdomains.
    3. 

                      
  3. Port Scanning: Aquatone can perform port scanning to identify open ports on web servers, aiding in the detection of additional services.
    4. 

                      
  4. HTTP Header Analysis: It analyzes HTTP headers to provide information about the web server, technologies in use, and potential security headers.
    5. 

                      
  5. Generate Reports: Aquatone can generate HTML reports that include screenshots, port scan results, and other relevant information for documentation and analysis.
    6. 

                      
  6. Integration with Other Tools: The tool supports integration with various other security tools, allowing users to incorporate Aquatone into their existing workflows.
    7. 

                      
  7. Easy-to-Use Command-Line Interface: Aquatone features a command-line interface that is designed to be user-friendly and efficient for both beginners and experienced users.
    8. 

                      
  8. Parallel Execution: The tool is capable of executing tasks in parallel, enhancing its speed and efficiency when scanning multiple web assets.
    9. 
                  


                  

              
              



              
                Basic command


                help

                
                cat websites.txt | ./aquatone
              
              
                


                
                aquatone guide
              
                


              
              



              


            



            


            

              


              

  

    
    
  





  

    
    

  

    
    
    
    
    


  





  







  
Nmap, short for "Network Mapper," is a free and open-source (under the terms of the GNU General Public License) utility for network exploration and security auditing. It was designed to rapidly scan large networks, although it works fine against single hosts. Nmap uses raw IP packets in novel ways to determine what hosts are available on the network, what services (application name and version) those hosts are offering, what operating systems (and OS versions) they are running, 
  what type of packet filters/firewalls are in use, and dozens of other characteristics.
   It was designed to be a robustup to the many network hurdles thrown up by network administrators. Nmap was named "Information Security Product of the Year" by Linux Journal.


  
Key Features of Nmap:

  
    
    
  • Host Discovery: Nmap can identify hosts on a network using a variety of techniques, such as ARP, ICMP, TCP, UDP, and others.
    • 
    
  • Port Scanning: Nmap can scan for open ports on a target system and identify the services running on those ports.
    • 
    
  • Version Detection: Nmap can identify the specific application version running on open ports, which can help identify potential vulnerabilities.
    • 
    
  • OS Detection: Nmap can attempt to determine the operating system and version running on a target system.
    • 
    
  • Scriptable Interface (NSE): Nmap supports a powerful and flexible scripting engine that allows you to write custom scripts to extend Nmap's functionality for various security assessment tasks.
    • 
    
  • Performance Tuning: Nmap offers various options to adjust the timing and performance of network scans to balance speed and stealth.
    • 
    
  • Output Formats: Nmap can generate output in various formats, such as plain text, XML, grepable, and others, which can be useful for further processing and analysis.
    • 
    
  • Integration with Other Tools: Nmap can be easily integrated with other network security tools, such as Metasploit, for more comprehensive security assessments.
    • 
  






Basic Scan
Version Detection (-sV) H
TTP-Vuln-Scanner (-sV --script=http-vuln-scanner)
DNS-Brute (-sU --script=dns-brute)

help


nmap example.com




nmap -sV example.com




nmap -sV --script=http-vuln-scanner example.com  >




nmap -sU --script=dns-brute example.com





nmap github











  

  


    
      
How to Crawl a Website using Burp Crawler


       
    
           
  1. Install Burp Suite:
               
    Download and install Burp Suite from the official website https://portswigger.net/burp.
    
           
    2. 

           
  2. Configure Browser:
               
    Set up your browser to use Burp Suite as a proxy. Burp Suite runs on localhost and port 8080 by default.
    
           
    3. 

           
  3. Launch Burp Suite:
               
    Start Burp Suite and open the "Proxy" tab. Make sure the "Intercept is on" button is clicked.
    
           
    4. 

           
  4. Configure Browser Proxy:
               
    In your browser settings, configure the proxy settings to point to localhost on port 8080 (or the port you have configured in Burp Suite).
    
           
    5. 

           
  5. Visit the Target Website:
               
    Go to your browser and visit the target website. Burp Suite should capture the requests in the "Proxy" tab.
    
           
    6. 

           
  6. Crawler Setup:
               
    In Burp Suite, go to the "Target" tab and click on the "Site map" sub-tab.
    
               
    Right-click on the target domain or URL and select "Engagement tools" > "Spider."
    
               
    In the Spider tab, configure the settings such as "Scope," "Session handling," and other options according to your requirements.
    
               
    Click on the "Start" button to initiate the crawling process.
    
           
    7. 

           
  7. Monitor Progress:
               
    Switch to the "Spider" tab to monitor the progress of the crawling. You will see the URLs being visited and the results.
    
           
    8. 

           
  8. Review Results:
               
    After the crawling process is complete, you can review the results in the "Site map" tab. It will display all the discovered URLs along with associated details.
    
           
    9. 
       


  



  

  





  



ffuf is an acronym for “fuzz faster you fool!”. In one line, ffuf is an open-source web fuzzing tool developed in go used to identify hidden resources. But first, we understand what Fuzzing is? It is a process of sending random inputs to get errors or unexpected output. Sometimes fuzzing output provides a goldmine to an attacker in the form of the hidden admin page, injection errors, etc. In this article, we will see the installation and top 30 examples of ffuf web fuzzer.








  Basic Command
  Fuzz Parameters
  Fuzz Headers
  Fuzz URL (POST)
  Fuzz Vhost
  Find Subdomains

  
    
      ffuf -w <path-wordlist> -u 
      https://test-url/FUZZ
    
    
  

  
    
      ffuf -w <path-wordlist> -u 
      https://test-url?id=FUZZ
    
    
  

  
    
      ffuf -w <path-wordlist> -u 
      https://test-url -H "X-Header: FUZZ"
    
    
  

  
    
      ffuf -w <path-wordlist> -u 
      https://test-url -X POST -d "var=FUZZ"
    
    
  

  
    
      ffuf -w <path-vhosts> -u 
      https://test-url -H "Host: FUZZ"
    
    
  

  
    
      ffuf -w <path-wordlist> -u 
      https://test-url/ -H "Host: FUZZ.site.com"
    
    
  




  

  



  
Gau stands for get all URLs. It is a free and open-source tool available on GitHub which is used for extracting all the URLs from a given domain. This tool is free means you can download and use this tool free of cost. It is used for reconnaissance of subdomains. Gau is used for finding the URLs of the target website. This tool is used to find all URLs from a website/web application. This tool helps to get subdomains of all HTTPS as well as HTTP websites.

 




  Basic Scan


  help

  
  echo example.com | gau

  




  
  gau github

  



  

  

    

    
      
LinkFinder is a python script written to discover endpoints and their parameters in JavaScript files. This way penetration testers and bug hunters are able to gather new, hidden endpoints on the websites they are testing. Resulting in new testing ground, possibility containing new vulnerabilities. It does so by using jsbeautifier for python in combination with a fairly large regular expression. The regular expressions consists of four small regular expressions. These are responsible for finding:

   

    
  
  

  
    Basic Scan


    help

    
    python3 linkfinder.py -i example.com -d
  
    




    
    nmap github
  
    


  
  







  


    
    

  

    
    
    
    
    
    
    


  





  


    
    

Shodan is a search engine platform that enables users to locate internet-connected devices and identify the types of machines that are exposed to the internet.

      
CVE

      
The following query is used for searching CVEs in Shodan:

      
vuln:<CVE ID>

      
Example: vuln:CVE-2021-40438

      
An example of a CVE Shodan query and search results:

      
      
  
  


  

  

    

    

      
Censys acts as a digital detective, employing advanced techniques to systematically scan and index information about hosts and websites. This search engine for the internet goes beyond traditional search engines, focusing on the digital infrastructure itself.

  
Example:
Imagine a cybersecurity analyst using Censys to identify all publicly accessible devices within a specific network range. The Censys query ip:192.168.0.0/24 scans the entire range, providing a detailed list of devices, open ports, and services running on each machine.

  
ip:192.168.0.0/24

  
 

 

  
Applications in Cybersecurity

  
Censys plays a crucial role in fortifying cybersecurity efforts, helping professionals identify and address security gaps in real-time.

  
Example: 
An IT security team uses Censys to identify all devices in their organization with a specific welcome page. The Censys query 80.http.get.title: "Welcome to Our Corporate Network" allows them to pinpoint devices broadcasting this potentially sensitive information, securing these endpoints promptly.

  
80.http.get.title: "Welcome to Our Corporate Network"

  

  

  
Threat Intelligence

  
Censys’s role in threat intelligence is indispensable, allowing analysts to monitor changes in the digital landscape and stay ahead of emerging cyber threats.

  
Example: 
A threat intelligence analyst leverages Censys to track instances of a new malware strain. The Censys query tags.raw: "malware" helps monitor changes in the behavior and distribution of affected devices, offering valuable insights into the malware's lifecycle and potential targets.

  
tags.raw: "malware"

  

  

  
Network Administration and Monitoring

  
For network administrators, Censys becomes a powerful ally in managing and securing digital assets.

  
Example: 
A network administrator uses Censys to conduct regular scans for unauthorized IoT devices connected to the corporate network. The Censys query 443.https.tls.certificate.parsed.subject.organization: "Unknown IoT Vendor" helps identify and isolate devices with certificates from an unknown vendor, ensuring the network's integrity.

  
443.https.tls.certificate.parsed.subject.organization: "Unknown IoT Vendor"

  

  

  
API Integration and Automation

  
Censys offers an API for seamless integration with existing security infrastructure, enabling automation of routine tasks.

  
Example:
A cybersecurity team integrates Censys’s API with their vulnerability management system. The Censys query 443.https.tls.certificate.parsed.subject.organization: "Expired" automates the identification of devices with expired SSL certificates, streamlining the patching process and reducing the window of vulnerability.

  
443.https.tls.certificate.parsed.subject.organization: "Expired"

  

      
As demonstrated by these examples, Censys stands as a dynamic force in the cybersecurity landscape. Its internet-wide scanning capabilities, coupled with applications in threat intelligence and network administration, exemplify its crucial role in fortifying digital defenses.

  

  
  

  

  

	      
	      
	      
ZoomEye is a powerful cybersecurity search engine designed for security researchers and penetration testers. It enables users to search for exposed devices and open services on the internet, helping identify potential vulnerabilities and analyze network risks.

    
With ZoomEye, you can explore various devices, including servers, webcams, IoT devices, and more. It offers detailed filtering options and allows users to gather intelligence for security assessments and incident response.

  
			  
			  
			 

	  
	  

  

  
	  
FOFA.info is a comprehensive cybersecurity search engine that allows users to discover exposed assets, analyze vulnerabilities, and collect valuable security intelligence from the internet.

    
FOFA.info is widely used by security researchers and organizations to identify misconfigured systems, open ports, and IoT devices. Its advanced search capabilities make it an essential tool for vulnerability assessment and security research.

  
  
  
  

  



    
    

        
Have you ever struggled to find the information you need while wading through many Google search results? If so, you are not by yourself. The good news is that there is a fix: Google dork commands. We’ll go through how to utilize these commands to focus your search and locate online treasures in this piece.

     
  



	
  Find Login Pages
  Find Sensitive Directories
  Search for Exposed Files
  Discover Vulnerable Websites
  Find Publicly Exposed Cameras

  
    
      intitle:"login" inurl:"admin" 
      site:example.com
    
    
  

  
    
      "index of /" "parent directory" 
      site:example.com
    
    
  

  
    
      ext:sql | ext:db | ext:bak 
      site:example.com
    
    
  

  
    
      inurl:"php?id=" 
      site:example.com
    
    
  

  
    
      inurl:/view/index.shtml 
      site:example.com
    
    
  





  

  

    

    

        
The Use of Pastebin for Sharing Stolen Data

   
                
Pastebin is a popular website for storing and sharing text. Though it's mostly used for distributing legitimate data, it seems to be frequently used as a public repository of stolen information, such as network configuration details and authentication records. Various hacker groups and individuals also use Pastebin to distribute their loot the highest—a trend perhaps initially set in motion by LulzSec.

                
What's Popular on Pastebin

                
To get a taste for the kind of information available on Pastebin, take a look at its Trending Pastes page. It's not uncommon for the most popular pages to include gems such as:

                
    
                    
  • A listing of subnet addresses that belong to various corporations
    • 
                    
  •  
    • 
                    
  • A dump of compromised Facebook accounts, complete with email addresses and passwords
    • 
                    
  •  
    • 
                    
  • An internal user database of a compromised website, including email addresses, privileges and password hashes
    • 
                    
  •  
    • 
                    
  • An export of a users table from a compromised database, including usernames and passwords
    • 
                

  
  

  

  

	  
		  
OSINT refers to the process of collecting and analyzing publicly available data from various sources to gather intelligence. This information can be used for various purposes, including security research, threat intelligence, and investigative work.

    
OSINT involves gathering information from publicly accessible sources such as websites, social media, government databases, and even online forums. It is an essential tool for cybersecurity professionals, law enforcement, and private investigators.


    
OSINT Framework

    
The OSINT Framework is a collection of resources and tools that help streamline the OSINT collection process. It is widely used to gather information for investigation, penetration testing, and threat intelligence. Below are key components of the OSINT Framework:

    
    
        
  • Search Engines: Tools to search for publicly available information on the internet, such as Google, Bing, and DuckDuckGo.
    • 
        
  • Social Media Investigation: Platforms like Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, and Instagram for collecting personal and organizational data.
    • 
        
  • Geolocation Tools: Services like Google Maps and GeoHack to find location-based information.
    • 
        
  • Domain and IP Lookup: Tools such as WHOIS, DNSstuff, and Shodan for obtaining domain and IP-related information.
    • 
        
  • Metadata Analysis: Tools like Metagoofil and FOCA for analyzing metadata in documents to reveal sensitive information.
    • 
        
  • Public Data and Archives: Repositories like Archive.org and government websites for collecting public records.
    • 
        
  • Communication Intercepting: Tools for collecting data from public messaging systems, emails, or forums.
    • 
    

	  
	  
	  
	  
  
  







  





            

            

              
              

  

    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    

  





  



    

Explore example.com Manually..




  

  

    
    

  
This section describes how to test various metadata files for information leakage of the web application’s path(s), or functionality. Furthermore, the list of directories that are to be avoided by Spiders, Robots, or Crawlers can also be created as a dependency for Map execution paths through application. Other information may also be collected to identify attack surface, technology details, or for use in social engineering engagement.

  
  

  
  Find Hidden Directories
  Search for Hidden Files
  Discover Admin Panels
  Find Backup Files
  Locate Hidden Directories with Indexes

  
    
      "index of" inurl:"/admin" 
      site:example.com
    
    
  

  
    
      "index of" inurl:"/backup" 
      site:example.com
    
    
  

  
    
      intitle:"Admin Login" inurl:"/admin" 
      site:example.com
    
    
  

  
    
      "index of" ext:bak | ext:sql | ext:tar 
      site:example.com
    
    
  

  
    
      "index of" inurl:"/hidden" 
      site:example.com
    
    
  


  

  

  
Test Objectives

  
    
      
  • Identify hidden or obfuscated paths and functionality through the analysis of metadata files.
    • 
      
  •  
    • 
      
  • Extract and map other information that could lead to better understanding of the systems at hand.
    • 
  

  
How to Test

  

      
Any of the actions performed below with wget could also be done with curl. Many Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST) tools such as ZAP and Burp Suite include checks or parsing for these resources as part of their spider/crawler functionality. They can also be identified using various Google Dorks or leveraging advanced search features such as inurl:.

  

  
Robots

  
Web Spiders, Robots, or Crawlers retrieve a web page and then recursively traverse hyperlinks to retrieve further web content. Their accepted behavior is specified by the Robots Exclusion Protocol of the robots.txt file in the web root directory.

  
As an example, the beginning of the robots.txt file from Google sampled on 2020 May 5 is quoted below:

  

      

          
User-agent: *
  Disallow: /search
  Allow: /search/about
  Allow: /search/static
  Allow: /search/howsearchworks
  Disallow: /sdch
  ...
  

      

  

  
The User-Agent directive refers to the specific web spider/robot/crawler. For example, the User-Agent: Googlebot refers to the spider from Google while User-Agent: bingbot refers to a crawler from Microsoft. User-Agent: * in the example above applies to all web spiders/robots/crawlers.

  
The Disallow directive specifies which resources are prohibited by spiders/robots/crawlers. In the example above, the following are prohibited:

  

      

          
...
  Disallow: /search
  ...
  Disallow: /sdch
  ...
  

      

  

  
Web spiders/robots/crawlers can intentionally ignore the Disallow directives specified in a robots.txt file, such as those from Social Networks to ensure that shared linked are still valid. Hence, robots.txt should not be considered as a mechanism to enforce restrictions on how web content is accessed, stored, or republished by third parties.

  
The robots.txt file is retrieved from the web root directory of the web server. For example, to retrieve the robots.txt from www.google.com using wget or curl:

  

      

          
$ curl -O -Ss http://www.google.com/robots.txt && head -n5 robots.txt
  User-agent: *
  Disallow: /search
  Allow: /search/about
  Allow: /search/static
  Allow: /search/howsearchworks
  ...
  

      

  

  
Analyze robots.txt Using Google Webmaster Tools

  
Web site owners can use the Google “Analyze robots.txt” function to analyze the website as part of its Google Webmaster Tools. This tool can assist with testing and the procedure is as follows:

  
    
      
  1. Sign into Google Webmaster Tools with a Google account.
    2. 
      
  2.  
    3. 
      
  3. On the dashboard, enter the URL for the site to be analyzed.
    4. 
      
  4.  
    5. 
      
  5. Choose between the available methods and follow the on screen instruction.
    6. 
  

  
META Tags

  
<META> tags are located within the HEAD section of each HTML document and should be consistent across a web site in the event that the robot/spider/crawler start point does not begin from a document link other than webroot i.e. a deep link. Robots directive can also be specified through use of a specific META tag.

  
Robots META Tag

  
If there is no <META NAME="ROBOTS" ... > entry then the “Robots Exclusion Protocol” defaults to INDEX,FOLLOW respectively. Therefore, the other two valid entries defined by the “Robots Exclusion Protocol” are prefixed with NO... i.e. NOINDEX and NOFOLLOW.

  
Based on the Disallow directive(s) listed within the robots.txt file in webroot, a regular expression search for <META NAME="ROBOTS" within each web page is undertaken and the result compared to the robots.txt file in webroot.

  
Miscellaneous META Information Tags

  
Organizations often embed informational META tags in web content to support various technologies such as screen readers, social networking previews, search engine indexing, etc. Such meta-information can be of value to testers in identifying technologies used, and additional paths/functionality to explore and test. The following meta information was retrieved from www.whitehouse.gov via View Page Source on 2020 May 05:

  

      

          
...
  <meta property="og:locale" content="en_US" />
  <meta property="og:type" content="website" />
  <meta property="og:title" content="The White House" />
  <meta property="og:description" content="We, the citizens of America, are now joined in a great national effort to rebuild our country and to restore its promise for all. – President Donald Trump." />
  <meta property="og:url" content="https://www.whitehouse.gov/" />
  <meta property="og:site_name" content="The White House" />
  <meta property="fb:app_id" content="1790466490985150" />
  <meta property="og:image" content="https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/wh.gov-share-img_03-1024x538.png" />
  <meta property="og:image:secure_url" content="https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/wh.gov-share-img_03-1024x538.png" />
  <meta name="twitter:card" content="summary_large_image" />
  <meta name="twitter:description" content="We, the citizens of America, are now joined in a great national effort to rebuild our country and to restore its promise for all. – President Donald Trump." />
  <meta name="twitter:title" content="The White House" />
  <meta name="twitter:site" content="@whitehouse" />
  <meta name="twitter:image" content="https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/wh.gov-share-img_03-1024x538.png" />
  <meta name="twitter:creator" content="@whitehouse" />
  ...
  <meta name="apple-mobile-web-app-title" content="The White House">
  <meta name="application-name" content="The White House">
  <meta name="msapplication-TileColor" content="#0c2644">
  <meta name="theme-color" content="#f5f5f5">
  ...
  

      

  

  
Sitemaps

  
A sitemap is a file where a developer or organization can provide information about the pages, videos, and other files offered by the site or application, and the relationship between them. Search engines can use this file to more intelligently explore your site. Testers can use sitemap.xml files to learn more about the site or application to explore it more completely.

  
The following excerpt is from Google’s primary sitemap retrieved 2020 May 05.

  

      

          
$ wget --no-verbose https://www.google.com/sitemap.xml && head -n8 sitemap.xml
  2020-05-05 12:23:30 URL:https://www.google.com/sitemap.xml [2049] -> "sitemap.xml" [1]

  <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
  <sitemapindex xmlns="http://www.google.com/schemas/sitemap/0.84">
    <sitemap>
      <loc>https://www.google.com/gmail/sitemap.xml</loc>
    </sitemap>
    <sitemap>
      <loc>https://www.google.com/forms/sitemaps.xml</loc>
    </sitemap>
  ...
  

      

  

  
Exploring from there a tester may wish to retrieve the gmail sitemap https://www.google.com/gmail/sitemap.xml:

  

      

          
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
  <urlset xmlns="http://www.sitemaps.org/schemas/sitemap/0.9" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
    <url>
      <loc>https://www.google.com/intl/am/gmail/about/</loc>
      <xhtml:link href="https://www.google.com/gmail/about/" hreflang="x-default" rel="alternate"/>
      <xhtml:link href="https://www.google.com/intl/el/gmail/about/" hreflang="el" rel="alternate"/>
      <xhtml:link href="https://www.google.com/intl/it/gmail/about/" hreflang="it" rel="alternate"/>
      <xhtml:link href="https://www.google.com/intl/ar/gmail/about/" hreflang="ar" rel="alternate"/>
  ...
  

      

  

  
Security TXT

  
security.txt is a proposed standard which allows websites to define security policies and contact details. There are multiple reasons this might be of interest in testing scenarios, including but not limited to:

  
    
      
  • Identifying further paths or resources to include in discovery/analysis.
    • 
      
  •  
    • 
      
  • Open Source intelligence gathering.
    • 
      
  •  
    • 
      
  • Finding information on Bug Bounties, etc.
    • 
      
  •  
    • 
      
  • Social Engineering.
    • 
  

  
The file may be present either in the root of the webserver or in the .well-known/ directory. Ex:

  
    
      
  • https://example.com/security.txt
    • 
      
  •  
    • 
      
  • https://example.com/.well-known/security.txt
    • 
  

  
Here is a real world example retrieved from LinkedIn 2020 May 05:

  

      

          
$ wget --no-verbose https://www.linkedin.com/.well-known/security.txt && cat security.txt
  2020-05-07 12:56:51 URL:https://www.linkedin.com/.well-known/security.txt [333/333] -> "security.txt" [1]
  # Conforms to IETF `draft-foudil-securitytxt-07`
  Contact: mailto:security@linkedin.com
  Contact: https://www.linkedin.com/help/linkedin/answer/62924
  Encryption: https://www.linkedin.com/help/linkedin/answer/79676
  Canonical: https://www.linkedin.com/.well-known/security.txt
  Policy: https://www.linkedin.com/help/linkedin/answer/62924
  

      

  

  
Humans TXT

  
humans.txt is an initiative for knowing the people behind a website. It takes the form of a text file that contains information about the different people who have contributed to building the website. See humanstxt for more info. This file often (though not always) contains information for career or job sites/paths.

  
The following example was retrieved from Google 2020 May 05:

  

      

          
$ wget --no-verbose  https://www.google.com/humans.txt && cat humans.txt
  2020-05-07 12:57:52 URL:https://www.google.com/humans.txt [286/286] -> "humans.txt" [1]
  Google is built by a large team of engineers, designers, researchers, robots, and others in many different sites across the globe. It is updated continuously, and built with more tools and technologies than we can shake a stick at. If you'd like to help us out, see careers.google.com.
  

      

  

  
Other .well-known Information Sources

  
There are other RFCs and Internet drafts which suggest standardized uses of files within the .well-known/ directory. Lists of which can be found here or here.

  
It would be fairly simple for a tester to review the RFC/drafts are create a list to be supplied to a crawler or fuzzer, in order to verify the existence or content of such files.

  
Tools

  
    
      
  • Browser (View Source or Dev Tools functionality)
    • 
      
  • curl
    • 
      
  • wget
    • 
      
  • Burp Suite
    • 
      
  • ZAP
    • 
  

  
  

  

  

    
    
    
It is very common, and even recommended, for programmers to include detailed comments and metadata on their source code. However, comments and metadata included in the HTML code might reveal internal information that should not be available to potential attackers. Comments and metadata review should be done in order to determine if any information is being leaked. Additionally some applications may leak information in the body of redirect responses.

    
For modern web apps, the use of client-side JavaScript for the frontend is becoming more popular. Popular frontend construction technologies use client-side JavaScript like ReactJS, AngularJS, or Vue. Similar to the comments and metadata in HTML code, many programmers also hardcode sensitive information in JavaScript variables on the frontend. Sensitive information can include (but is not limited to): Private API Keys (e.g. an unrestricted Google Map API Key), internal IP addresses, sensitive routes (e.g. route to hidden admin pages or functionality), or even credentials. This sensitive information can be leaked from such frontend JavaScript code. A review should be done in order to determine if any sensitive information leaked which could be used by attackers for abuse.

    
For large web applications, performance issues are a big concern to programmers. Programmers have used different methods to optimize frontend performance, including Syntactically Awesome Style Sheets (Sass), Sassy CSS (SCSS), webpack, etc. Using these technologies, frontend code will sometimes become harder to understand and difficult to debug, and because of it, programmers often deploy source map files for debugging purposes. A “source map” is a special file that connects a minified/uglified version of an asset (CSS or JavaScript) to the original authored version. Programmers are still debating whether or not to bring source map files to the production environment. However, it is undeniable that source map files or files for debugging if released to the production environment will make their source more human-readable. It can make it easier for attackers to find vulnerabilities from the frontend or collect sensitive information from it. JavaScript code review should be done in order to determine if any debug files are exposed from the frontend. Depending on the context and sensitivity of the project, a security expert should decide whether the files should exist in the production environment or not.

    
Test Objectives

    
    
      
  • Review web page comments, metadata, and redirect bodies to find any information leakage.
    • 
      
  •  
    • 
      
  • Gather JavaScript files and review the JS code to better understand the application and to find any information leakage.
    • 
      
  •  
    • 
      
  • Identify if source map files or other frontend debug files exist.
    • 
    

    
How to Test

    
Review Web Page Comments and Metadata

    
HTML comments are often used by the developers to include debugging information about the application. Sometimes, they forget about the comments and they leave them in production environments. Testers should look for HTML comments which start with <!--.

    
Check HTML source code for comments containing sensitive information that can help the attacker gain more insight about the application. It might be SQL code, usernames and passwords, internal IP addresses, or debugging information.

    

      

          
...
    <div class="table2">
    <div class="col1">1</div><div class="col2">Mary</div>
    <div class="col1">2</div><div class="col2">Peter</div>
    <div class="col1">3</div><div class="col2">Joe</div>

    <!-- Query: SELECT id, name FROM app.users WHERE active='1' -->

    </div>
    ...
    

      

    

    
The tester may even find something like this:

    

      

          
<!-- Use the DB administrator password for testing:  f@keP@a$$w0rD -->
    

      

    

    
Check HTML version information for valid version numbers and Data Type Definition (DTD) URLs

    

      

          
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/strict.dtd">
    

      

    

    
    
      
  • strict.dtd – default strict DTD
    • 
      
  •  
    • 
      
  • loose.dtd – loose DTD
    • 
      
  •  
    • 
      
  • frameset.dtd – DTD for frameset documents
    • 
    

    
Some META tags do not provide active attack vectors but instead allow an attacker to profile an application:

    

      

          
<META name="Author" content="Andrew Muller">
    

      

    

    
A common (but not WCAG compliant) META tag is Refresh.

    

      

          
<META http-equiv="Refresh" content="15;URL=https://www.owasp.org/index.html">
    

      

    

    
A common use for META tag is to specify keywords that a search engine may use to improve the quality of search results.

    

      

          
<META name="keywords" lang="en-us" content="OWASP, security, sunshine, lollipops">
    

      

    

    
Although most web servers manage search engine indexing via the robots.txt file, it can also be managed by META tags. The tag below will advise robots to not index and not follow links on the HTML page containing the tag.

    

      

          
<META name="robots" content="none">
    

      

    

    
The Platform for Internet Content Selection (PICS) and Protocol for Web Description Resources (POWDER) provide infrastructure for associating metadata with Internet content.

    
Identifying JavaScript Code and Gathering JavaScript Files

    
Programmers often hardcode sensitive information with JavaScript variables on the frontend. Testers should check HTML source code and look for JavaScript code between <script> and </script> tags. Testers should also identify external JavaScript files to review the code (JavaScript files have the file extension .js and name of the JavaScript file usually put in the src (source) attribute of a <script> tag).

    
Check JavaScript code for any sensitive information leaks which could be used by attackers to further abuse or manipulate the system. Look for values such as: API keys, internal IP addresses, sensitive routes, or credentials. For example:

    

      

          
const myS3Credentials = {
    accessKeyId: config('AWSS3AccessKeyID'),
    secretAccessKey: config('AWSS3SecretAccessKey'),
    };
    

      

    

    
The tester may even find something like this:

    

      

          
var conString = "tcp://postgres:1234@localhost/postgres";
    

      

    

    
When an API Key is found, testers can check if the API Key restrictions are set per service or by IP, HTTP referrer, application, SDK, etc.

    
For example, if testers find a Google Map API Key, they can check if this API Key is restricted by IP or restricted only per the Google Map APIs. If the Google API Key is restricted only per the Google Map APIs, attackers can still use that API Key to query unrestricted Google Map APIs and the application owner must pay for that.

    

      

          

    <script type="application/json">
    ...
    {"GOOGLE_MAP_API_KEY":"AIzaSyDUEBnKgwiqMNpDplT6ozE4Z0XxuAbqDi4", "RECAPTCHA_KEY":"6LcPscEUiAAAAHOwwM3fGvIx9rsPYUq62uRhGjJ0"}
    ...
    </script>
    

      

    

    
In some cases, testers may find sensitive routes from JavaScript code, such as links to internal or hidden admin pages.

    

      

          
<script type="application/json">
    ...
    "runtimeConfig":{"BASE_URL_VOUCHER_API":"https://staging-voucher.victim.net/api", "BASE_BACKOFFICE_API":"https://10.10.10.2/api", "ADMIN_PAGE":"/hidden_administrator"}
    ...
    </script>
    

      

    

    
Identifying Source Map Files

    
Source map files will usually be loaded when DevTools open. Testers can also find source map files by adding the “.map” extension after the extension of each external JavaScript file. For example, if a tester sees a /static/js/main.chunk.js file, they can then check for its source map file by visiting /static/js/main.chunk.js.map.

    
Check source map files for any sensitive information that can help the attacker gain more insight about the application. For example:

    

      

          
{
    "version": 3,
    "file": "static/js/main.chunk.js",
    "sources": [
      "/home/sysadmin/cashsystem/src/actions/index.js",
      "/home/sysadmin/cashsystem/src/actions/reportAction.js",
      "/home/sysadmin/cashsystem/src/actions/cashoutAction.js",
      "/home/sysadmin/cashsystem/src/actions/userAction.js",
      "..."
    ],
    "..."
    }
    

      

    

    
When sites load source map files, the frontend source code will become readable and easier to debug.

    
Identify Redirect Responses which Leak Information

    
Although redirect responses are not generally expected to contain any significant web content there is no assurance that they cannot contain content. So, while series 300 (redirect) responses often contain “redirecting to https://example.com/” type content they may also leak content.

    
Consider a situation in which a redirect response is the result of an authentication or authorization check, if that check fails the server may respond redirecting the user back to a “safe” or “default” page, yet the redirect response itself may still contain content which isn’t shown in the browser but is indeed transmitted to the client. This can be seen either leveraging browser developer tools or via a personal proxy (such as ZAP, Burp, Fiddler, or Charles).

    
Tools

    
    
      
  • Wget
    • 
      
  • Eyeballs
    • 
      
  • Curl
    • 
      
  • Zed Attack Proxy (ZAP)
    • 
      
  • Burp Suite
    • 
      
  • Waybackurls
    • 
      
  • Google Maps API Scanner
    • 
    

    
    

  

  

    

    

      
Testing for Browser Cache Weaknesses

      
      
In this phase the tester checks that the application correctly instructs the browser to not retain sensitive data.
      
Browsers can store information for purposes of caching and history. Caching is used to improve performance, so that previously displayed information doesn’t need to be downloaded again. History mechanisms are used for user convenience, so the user can see exactly what they saw at the time when the resource was retrieved. If sensitive information is displayed to the user (such as their address, credit card details, Social Security Number, or username), then this information could be stored for purposes of caching or history, and therefore retrievable through examining the browser’s cache or by simply pressing the browser’s Back button.

      
Test Objectives

      
    
          
  • Review if the application stores sensitive information on the client-side.
    • 
          
  •  
    • 
          
  • Review if access can occur without authorization.
    • 
      

      
How to Test

      
Browser History

      
Technically, the Back button is a history and not a cache (see Caching in HTTP: History Lists). The cache and the history are two different entities. However, they share the same weakness of presenting previously displayed sensitive information.

      
The first and simplest test consists of entering sensitive information into the application and logging out. Then the tester clicks the Back button of the browser to check whether previously displayed sensitive information can be accessed whilst unauthenticated.

      
If by pressing the Back button the tester can access previous pages but not access new ones, then it is not an authentication issue, but a browser history issue. If these pages contain sensitive data, it means that the application did not forbid the browser from storing it.

      
Authentication does not necessarily need to be involved in the testing. For example, when a user enters their email address in order to sign up to a newsletter, this information could be retrievable if not properly handled.

      
The Back button can be stopped from showing sensitive data. This can be done by:

      
    
          
  • Delivering the page over HTTPS.
    • 
          
  •  
    • 
          
  • Setting Cache-Control: must-revalidate
    • 
      

      
Browser Cache

      
Here testers check that the application does not leak any sensitive data into the browser cache. In order to do that, they can use a proxy (such as ZAP) and search through the server responses that belong to the session, checking that for every page that contains sensitive information the server instructed the browser not to cache any data. Such a directive can be issued in the HTTP response headers with the following directives:

      
    
          
  • Cache-Control: no-cache, no-store
    • 
          
  •  
    • 
          
  • Expires: 0
    • 
          
  •  
    • 
          
  • Pragma: no-cache
    • 
      

      
These directives are generally robust, although additional flags may be necessary for the Cache-Control header in order to better prevent persistently linked files on the file system. These include:

      
    
          
  • Cache-Control: must-revalidate, max-age=0, s-maxage=0
    • 
      

      

          

              
HTTP/1.1:
      Cache-Control: no-cache
      

          

      

      

          

              
HTTP/1.0:
      Pragma: no-cache
      Expires: "past date or illegal value (e.g., 0)"
      

          

      

      
For instance, if testers are testing an e-commerce application, they should look for all pages that contain a credit card number or some other financial information, and check that all those pages enforce the no-cache directive. If they find pages that contain critical information but that fail to instruct the browser not to cache their content, they know that sensitive information will be stored on the disk, and they can double-check this simply by looking for the page in the browser cache.

      
The exact location where that information is stored depends on the client operating system and on the browser that has been used. Here are some examples:

      
    
          
  • Mozilla Firefox:    
      
                  
    • Unix/Linux: ~/.cache/mozilla/firefox/
      • 
                  
    •      
      • 
                  
    • Windows: C:\Users\<user_name>\AppData\Local\Mozilla\Firefox\Profiles\<profile-id>\Cache2\
      • 
              
    
          
    • 
          
  •  
    • 
          
  • Internet Explorer:    
      
                  
    • C:\Users\<user_name>\AppData\Local\Microsoft\Windows\INetCache\
      • 
              
    
          
    • 
          
  •  
    • 
          
  • Chrome:    
      
                  
    • Windows: C:\Users\<user_name>\AppData\Local\Google\Chrome\User Data\Default\Cache
      • 
                  
    •      
      • 
                  
    • Unix/Linux: ~/.cache/google-chrome
      • 
              
    
          
    • 
      

      
Reviewing Cached Information

      
Firefox provides functionality for viewing cached information, which may be to your benefit as a tester. Of course the industry has also produced various extensions, and external apps which you may prefer or need for Chrome, Internet Explorer, or Edge.

      
Cache details are also available via developer tools in most modern browsers, such as Firefox, Chrome, and Edge. With Firefox it is also possible to use the URL about:cache to check cache details.

      
Check Handling for Mobile Browsers

      
Handling of cache directives may be completely different for mobile browsers. Therefore, testers should start a new browsing session with clean caches and take advantage of features like Chrome’s Device Mode or Firefox’s Responsive Design Mode to re-test or separately test the concepts outlined above.

      
Additionally, personal proxies such as ZAP and Burp Suite allow the tester to specify which User-Agent should be sent by their spiders/crawlers. This could be set to match a mobile browser User-Agent string and used to see which caching directives are sent by the application being tested.

      
Gray-Box Testing

      
The methodology for testing is equivalent to the black-box case, as in both scenarios testers have full access to the server response headers and to the HTML code. However, with gray-box testing, the tester may have access to account credentials that will allow them to test sensitive pages that are accessible only to authenticated users.

      
Tools

      
    
          
  • Zed Attack Proxy (ZAP)
    • 
      

  
  



  

  



    
       
A User Agent (UA) is a string sent by a web browser or other client to a web server that identifies the client software, operating system, and other relevant details about the device making the request.

    
User agents are typically used by websites to tailor content and services to specific devices or browsers. They also help in web analytics, load testing, and monitoring user interactions. Security researchers often analyze user agents to identify potential vulnerabilities or anomalous behavior.


    
Common Uses of User Agents

    
    
        
  • Device Identification: Web servers use the UA to detect the type of device or browser making the request (e.g., mobile, desktop).
    • 
        
  • Content Customization: Websites may serve different content or layouts based on the user agent string.
    • 
        
  • Browser Compatibility: UA strings help servers check if the client's browser supports certain features, like HTML5 or CSS3.
    • 
        
  • Security and Logging: User agents can be used to detect unusual activity or bot traffic.
    • 
    


    
Example of a User Agent String

    
A typical User-Agent string might look like this:

    
        Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/91.0.4472.124 Safari/537.36
    

  
  


  

  

    
      
      
Web server fingerprinting is the process of identifying the software and version running on a web server by analyzing various clues that can be found in HTTP responses, headers, or other exposed information.

    
Fingerprinting a web server is an essential step in web application security assessments, as it helps security professionals understand the potential vulnerabilities associated with the server software. By identifying the web server, its version, and configurations, attackers and defenders alike can focus on the most relevant weaknesses or attack vectors.


    
Methods of Web Server Fingerprinting

    
    
        
  • HTTP Headers: Analyzing headers like "Server" can provide clues about the web server type and version. For example, Apache or Nginx servers may expose information like "Apache/2.4.41 (Unix)" in the "Server" header.
    • 
        
  • Responses to Specific Requests: Certain servers have unique responses to common HTTP requests. For instance, the default page or error messages may reveal the server's identity.
    • 
        
  • DNS Queries: Reverse DNS lookups or specific subdomains (like "server1" or "admin") can sometimes indicate server information.
    • 
        
  • Fingerprinting Tools: Specialized tools can automate the process of identifying server types and versions by analyzing server responses and behaviors.
    • 
    


    
Nikto Tool for Web Server Fingerprinting

    
Nikto is an open-source web server scanner that is widely used for discovering vulnerabilities in web servers, including identifying the server type and version. It performs comprehensive checks against over 6,700 vulnerabilities, including outdated server software, misconfigurations, and other common issues.

    
    
Key Features of Nikto

    
    
        
  • Server Fingerprinting: Nikto can detect the web server software (e.g., Apache, Nginx, IIS) and its version by analyzing headers and responses.
    • 
        
  • Security Vulnerability Detection: Nikto identifies common vulnerabilities such as cross-site scripting (XSS), SQL injection, and directory traversal.
    • 
        
  • Scanning for Misconfigurations: It can also detect insecure configurations, including overly permissive permissions, missing security patches, or outdated software.
    • 
        
  • Automated Scanning: Nikto automates the process of scanning multiple web servers or web applications, saving time in penetration testing and vulnerability assessments.
    • 
    


    
Using Nikto

    
To use Nikto for web server fingerprinting, you can run a command like this:

    
        nikto -h http://example.com
    

    
This command will scan the specified target, report potential vulnerabilities, and attempt to identify the server type and version.


    
Example Nikto Output

    
        - Nikto v2.1.6
        + Server: Apache/2.4.41 (Unix)
        + OS: Linux
        + HTTP Methods: GET, POST, OPTIONS, HEAD
        + Potentially Vulnerable Script: /cgi-bin/test.cgi
        + SSL: No SSL/TLS supported
    


  
  

	  
  Check Server Type
  Scan for Server Version
  Check for Vulnerabilities
  Find Server-Side Technologies
  Check for HTTP Methods
  Scan for Cookies
  Get Full Web Server Info

  
    
      nikto -h 
      https://example.com -display V
    
    
  

  
    
      nikto -h 
      https://example.com -Plugins=version
    
    
  

  
    
      nikto -h 
      https://example.com -Tuning 4
    
    
  

  
    
      nikto -h 
      https://example.com -Plugins=all
    
    
  

  
    
      nikto -h 
      https://example.com -Tuning 6
    
    
  

  
    
      nikto -h 
      https://example.com -Plugins=cookie
    
    
  

  
    
      nikto -h 
      https://example.com -display V -Plugins=all
    
    
  


  
  

  


  

  

      
		  
		  
Wappalyzer is a popular tool that helps identify the technologies used by a web application. It scans websites and provides detailed information about the technologies powering the site, including web servers, programming languages, frameworks, analytics tools, and more.

    
Wappalyzer makes it easy for security researchers, web developers, and businesses to understand the tech stack behind a website. By identifying the technologies used, it helps assess compatibility, security risks, and the overall structure of a web application.


    
Technologies Detected by Wappalyzer

    
Wappalyzer can detect a wide range of technologies, including but not limited to:

    
    
        
  • Web Servers: Identifies the type of web server hosting the application, such as Apache, Nginx, or Microsoft IIS.
    • 
        
  • JavaScript Frameworks: Detects popular JavaScript frameworks and libraries, including React, Angular, Vue.js, and jQuery.
    • 
        
  • Programming Languages: Wappalyzer can identify the server-side programming languages used, such as PHP, Python, Ruby, Node.js, and Java.
    • 
        
  • Content Management Systems (CMS): It can detect CMS platforms like WordPress, Joomla, Drupal, and Shopify, giving insight into the site's management tools.
    • 
        
  • E-Commerce Platforms: Identifies platforms like Magento, WooCommerce, and PrestaShop used for e-commerce websites.
    • 
        
  • Analytics and Tracking Tools: Wappalyzer can spot tools such as Google Analytics, Hotjar, and Mixpanel that are used for tracking user behavior and site performance.
    • 
        
  • Advertising Networks: It detects advertising and monetization platforms like Google AdSense, DoubleClick, and Amazon Affiliate.
    • 
        
  • Cloud Hosting Providers: Wappalyzer can identify cloud hosting services like Amazon Web Services (AWS), Google Cloud, Microsoft Azure, and others.
    • 
        
  • Security Tools: It can identify security technologies such as SSL certificates, content delivery networks (CDNs), and firewall services like Cloudflare and Sucuri.
    • 
    


    
How Wappalyzer Works

    
Wappalyzer works by analyzing HTTP headers, JavaScript, and HTML elements on a web page. It looks for specific signatures associated with different technologies. For example, it might check for a unique meta tag, HTTP response header, or specific file structure that is commonly used by a particular technology.

    
    
Example Wappalyzer Output

    
        Web Server: Apache/2.4.41 (Unix)
        JavaScript Frameworks: React, jQuery
        CMS: WordPress
        Programming Language: PHP
        Analytics: Google Analytics
        Hosting: Amazon Web Services (AWS)
    

      
      
      
      

		  
  Identify Web Technologies
  Check for Content Management Systems (CMS)
  Identify JavaScript Frameworks
  Detect Web Servers
  Check for Analytics Tools
  Identify E-commerce Platforms
  Detect Payment Processors

  
    
      wappalyzer --url 
      https://example.com
    
    
  

  
    
      wappalyzer --url 
      https://example.com --cms
    
    
  

  
    
      wappalyzer --url 
      https://example.com --javascript
    
    
  

  
    
      wappalyzer --url 
      https://example.com --webserver
    
    
  

  
    
      wappalyzer --url 
      https://example.com --analytics
    
    
  

  
    
      wappalyzer --url 
      https://example.com --ecommerce
    
    
  

  
    
      wappalyzer --url 
      https://example.com --payment
    
    
  


      
      


  

  

    
    
      
      
Applications have several types of functionalities and services, and those require access permissions based on the needs of the user. That user could be:

      
    
          
  • an administrator, where they manage the application functionalities.
    • 
          
  • an auditor, where they review the application transactions and provide a detailed report.
    • 
          
  • a support engineer, where they help customers debug and fix issues on their accounts.
    • 
          
  • a customer, where they interact with the application and benefit from its services.
    • 
      

      

      
Test Objectives

      
    
          
  • Identify and document roles used by the application.
    • 
          
  • Attempt to switch, change, or access another role.
    • 
          
  • Review the granularity of the roles and the needs behind the permissions given.
    • 
      

      

      
How to Test

      
Roles Identification

      
The tester should start by identifying the application roles being tested through any of the following methods:

      
    
          
  • Application documentation.
    • 
          
  • Guidance by the developers or administrators of the application.
    • 
          
  • Application comments.
    • 
          
  • Fuzz possible roles:    
      
                  
    • cookie variable (e.g. role=admin, isAdmin=True)
      • 
                  
    • account variable (e.g. Role: manager)
      • 
                  
    • hidden directories or files (e.g. /admin, /mod, /backups)
      • 
                  
    • switching to well known users (e.g. admin, backups, etc.)
      • 
              
    
          
    • 
      

      
Switching to Available Roles

      
After identifying possible attack vectors, the tester needs to test and validate that they can access the available roles.

      

          
Some applications define the roles of the user on creation, through rigorous checks and policies, or by ensuring that the user’s role is properly protected through a signature created by the backend. Finding that roles exist doesn’t mean that they’re a vulnerability.

      

    
      
    
          
  • Burp’s Autorize extension
    • 
      

    
    


  

  



    
    

    
Finding endpoints in a website typically involves identifying URLs or paths that correspond to specific functionalities or resources on the server. Here are some methods and tools that can help you discover endpoints:







  Find API Endpoints
  Find Directory Listings
  Find Hidden Admin Pages
  Search for Login Pages
  Search for Backup Files
  Find File Upload Endpoints
  Locate REST API Endpoints

  
    
      inurl:"/api/" 
      site:example.com
    
    
  

  
    
      intitle:"Index of" inurl:"/admin"
      site:example.com
    
    
  

  
    
      inurl:"/admin" intitle:"Admin Login"
      site:example.com
    
    
  

  
    
      inurl:"/login"
      site:example.com
    
    
  

  
    
      inurl:"/backup" OR inurl:"/old" 
      site:example.com
    
    
  

  
    
      inurl:"/upload" OR intitle:"File Upload"
      site:example.com
    
    
  

  
    
      inurl:"/v1" OR inurl:"/api/v1"
      site:example.com
    
    
  




    
    
        
  1. Manual Exploration:
            
      
                
    • View Page Source: Inspect the page source code (right-click on the webpage and select "View Page Source" or use browser developer tools) to identify potential endpoints embedded in JavaScript or HTML.
      • 
                
    • URL Patterns: Analyze the URL structure for patterns that may reveal additional endpoints.
      • 
            
    
        
    2. 

        
  2. Web Crawlers:
            
      
                
    • Use web crawling tools like Scrapy or BeautifulSoup in Python to crawl through the website and extract URLs.
      • 
            
    
        
    3. 

        
  3. Proxy Tools:
            
      
                
    • Intercept and analyze HTTP requests and responses using proxy tools such as Burp Suite or OWASP ZAP. This can help identify API endpoints and hidden URLs.
      • 
            
    
        
    4. 

        
  4. Browser Developer Tools:
            
      
                
    • Utilize browser developer tools (usually accessible by pressing F12 or right-clicking and selecting "Inspect") to monitor network activity. Look for API calls or resource requests.
      • 
            
    
        
    5. 

        
  5. Automated Scanning Tools:
            
      
                
    • Tools like Nikto, Wfuzz, or DirBuster can be used to automate the process of discovering endpoints by testing common paths and filenames.
      • 
            
    
        
    6. 

        
  6. API Documentation:
            
      
                
    • Check if the website has public API documentation. This can provide insights into available endpoints and their functionalities.
      • 
            
    
        
    7. 

        
  7. Wordlist Attack:
            
      
                
    • Use wordlist attacks with tools like DirBuster or Dirsearch to systematically try different paths and filenames.
      • 
            
    
        
    8. 

        
  8. Google Dorking:
            
      
                
    • Use Google dorking to search for publicly exposed documents or directories. For example, using search queries like site:example.com inurl:/api.
      • 
            
    
        
    9. 

        
  9. Bruteforcing:
            
      
                
    • In some cases, you might try brute-forcing potential endpoints by systematically trying different combinations of paths and filenames.
      • 
            
    
        
    10. 

        
  10. Fuzzing:
            
      
                
    • Use fuzzing tools like ffuf or wfuzz to discover hidden or unlinked endpoints by sending a large number of requests with various inputs.
      • 
            
    
        
    11. 
    






    
How Endpoints Look Like


    
Endpoints in a website are specific URLs or paths that are associated with particular functionalities or resources on the server. The structure and appearance of endpoints can vary depending on the website and the underlying technology. Here are some common examples of what endpoints might look like:


    
    
        
  1. RESTful API Endpoints:
            
      
                
    • https://api.example.com/users
      • 
                
    • https://api.example.com/products/123
      • 
                
    • https://api.example.com/orders?status=completed
      • 
            
    
        
    2. 

        
  2. Web Application Endpoints:
            
      
                
    • https://www.example.com/login
      • 
                
    • https://www.example.com/profile/settings
      • 
                https://www.example.com/search?q=query
            
    
        
    3. 
        
    Content Delivery Endpoints:
    
        
      
            
    • https://cdn.example.com/images/image.jpg
      • 
            
    • https://cdn.example.com/videos/video.mp4
      • 
        
    

        
    Resource Endpoints:
    
        
      
            
    • https://www.example.com/css/styles.css
      • 
            
    • https://www.example.com/js/script.js
      • 
        
    

        
    Parameterized Endpoints:
    
        
      
            
    • https://www.example.com/products?id=123
      • 
            
    • https://www.example.com/search?category=electronics&type=laptop
      • 
        
    

        
    RESTful API with Versioning:
    
        
      
            
    • https://api.example.com/v1/users
      • 
            
    • https://api.example.com/v2/products
      • 
        
    

        
    Pagination in Endpoints:
    
        
      
            
    • https://api.example.com/posts?page=1
      • 
            
    • https://api.example.com/posts?page=2
      • 
        
    

        
    Dynamic Endpoints:
    
        
      
            
    • https://www.example.com/user/john.doe
      • 
            
    • https://www.example.com/category/technology
      • 
        
    

        
    Authentication Endpoints:
    
        
      
            
    • https://www.example.com/auth/login
      • 
            
    • https://www.example.com/auth/logout
      • 
        
    

        
    WebSocket Endpoints:
    
        
      
            
    • wss://ws.example.com/chat
      • 
            
    • wss://ws.example.com/notifications
      • 
        
    



        

    







    
Entry Points in a Website and Examples


  
    
      
  1. Homepage: https://www.example.com/
    2. 

      
  2. Login Page: https://www.example.com/login
    3. 

      
  3. Registration Page: https://www.example.com/register
